questions.text: A stool sample is collected and processed for examination. The specimen is labeled at different levels as I, II, III, and IV. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) IV

Explanation:

Parasitic ova are definitively observed under a microscope at the final processed level, after appropriate concentration and staining techniques such as formalin-ethyl acetate sedimentation.

  • Level IV, bottom of the tube, contains protozoan cyst and ova.

sedimentation technique labelled" data-author="" data-hash="12366" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" height="593" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/uEO0ImuI5vUegVqMl1KS1746621226.png" width="458" />

Sedimentation technique

Sedimentation techniques and Flotation techniques are concentration techniques used to recover low numbers of parasites in stool samples.

  • Useful for epidemiological studies and assessing treatment response.
  • Detects eggs, cysts, and larvae but does not detect trophozoites, as these get destroyed in the process.
  • Sedimentation techniques:
    • Eggs and cysts settle at the bottom due to higher density.
    • Example: Formalin-ether concentration increases detection sensitivity by 8–10 times.
  • Flotation techniques:
    • Specimens are suspended in a denser medium (e.g., saturated salt solution) in which the eggs and cysts float.
    • Limitations: Cannot concentrate non-floating parasites (e.g., unfertilized Ascaris eggs).

questions.text: A lung biopsy from a post-renal transplant patient shows an infection. Which of the following stains is least useful in identifying the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Congo red

Explanation:

In a post-renal transplant patient with a lung infection, the presence of 45-degree branching hyphae on histology suggests Aspergillus infection. Stains like PAS, Gomori Methenamine Silver (GMS), and Fontana-Masson are useful for identifying fungal organisms. However, Congo red is not helpful in this context, as it is used to detect amyloid deposits (apple-green birefringence).

  • Culture: Colonies have a velvety to powdery surface and are characteristically coloured:
    • A.fumigatus - dark green ;
    • A.niger - black ;
    • A.flavus - yellow-green ;
    • A.terreus - beige coloured colonies.
  • Histopathology
    • Stain used - Lactophenol cotton blue
    • It demonstrates septate hyphae and acute angled (<45°) / Dichotomous branching.

  • Presence of galactomannan
  • Tissue sections: Biopsy (stained with GMS/PAS) (Option B, C ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the media?
questions.solution:
The correct option is:

B. CLED  - the given image is of CLED agar

Explanation:

  • CLED (Cystine Lactose Electrolyte-Deficient) medium is commonly used for the culture of urine specimens to isolate and identify microorganisms causing urinary tract infections (UTIs).

  • Lactose Fermentation Differentiation: CLED medium contains lactose as a carbohydrate source. Lactose-fermenting bacteria produce acid during the fermentation of lactose, leading to a change in the pH of the medium. This change in pH results in a color change of the indicator in the medium. Lactose-fermenting colonies appear yellow, while non–lactose fermenters appear pink or red.

Now, let's discuss the other options:

  1. Nutrient agar - this option is incorrect

    3.     Nutrient agar: This option is incorrect

    4 Blood Agar: this option is incorrect

questions.text: Which of the following helps in bacterial adhesion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Fimbriae

Explanation:

Fimbriae (also called pili) are hair-like appendages on the surface of bacteria.

  • They play a crucial role in bacterial adhesion to host tissues and surfaces, facilitating the formation of biofilms and the establishment of infections.
  • Fimbriae bind to specific receptors on host cells, allowing bacteria to colonize tissues.

Fimbriae

Definition

Fimbriae are thin, hair-like appendages found on the surface of many bacteria, primarily Gram-negative bacteria.

Structure

Fimbriae are composed of protein subunits called pilins. They are usually shorter and more numerous than flagella.

Types
  • Common (Type I) Fimbriae: Adhesive fimbriae that bind to mannose-containing receptors on host cells.
  • Sex Pili: Involved in bacterial conjugation and DNA transfer.

Functions
  • Adhesion: Fimbriae allow bacteria to adhere to surfaces, cells, and tissues, which is crucial for colonization and infection.
  • Biofilm Formation: Contribute to biofilm formation, protecting bacteria from environmental stresses.
  • Gene Transfer: Sex pili facilitates the transfer of genetic material between bacteria during conjugation, promoting genetic diversity and the spread of antibiotic resistance.
  • Motility: Usually not involved except Type IV Pili, particularly in Neisseria species, enabling a type of movement known as twitching motility.

Uses in Medicine
  • Target for Vaccines: Components of fimbriae can be used as antigens in vaccines to prevent bacterial infections.
  • Antimicrobial Targets: Inhibiting fimbrial function can prevent bacterial adhesion and biofilm formation, making it a potential target for new antibiotics.

Clinical Importance
  • Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs): Uropathogenic E. coli (UPEC) use Type 1 fimbriae to adhere to the urinary tract, causing UTIs.
  • Respiratory Infections: Bacteria like Bordetella pertussis (whooping cough) use fimbriae to adhere to the respiratory tract.
  • Gastrointestinal Infections: Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) use fimbriae to adhere to the intestinal mucosa, causing diarrhea.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Uses Type IV pili for surface attachment and biofilm formation.
  • Neisseria gonorrhoeae: Uses fimbriae for attachment to mucosal surfaces in the genitourinary tract.

Laboratory Identification
  • Hemagglutination Assay: Detects Type 1 fimbriae by their ability to agglutinate red blood cells.
  • Electron Microscopy: Visualizes fimbriae on the surface of bacteria.
  • Pellicle Formation: Observing pellicle formation on liquid culture surfaces can indicate the presence of fimbriae.

 

Incorrect Options:

Cytoplasmic membrane (Option A): The cytoplasmic membrane is involved in processes like energy generation, transport, and signal transduction, but it does not directly aid in bacterial adhesion.

Mesosomes (Option B): Mesosomes are invaginations of the cytoplasmic membrane and not directly involved in bacterial adhesion.

Lipopolysaccharides (Option D): Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are components of the outer membrane of gram-negative bacteria and play a role in the immune response (e.g., endotoxin activity), but they do not directly mediate bacterial adhesion.

questions.text: Which of the following is a bioterrorism Category A agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Anthrax

Explanation:

  • The CDC classifies bioterrorism agents into three categories (A, B, and C) based on their ease of dissemination, mortality rates, and public health impact.
 

Category A

Category B

Category C

Priority

High-priority agents posing a risk to national security

Second highest priority

Third highest priority with emerging pathogens

The reason they are classified into the respective categories:
  • Easily disseminated in the environment
  • High mortality risk
  • Cause public panic and social disruption
  • Requires special action for public health preparedness
  • Moderately easy to disseminate.
  • Moderate morbidity risk.
  • Requires enhanced disease surveillance.
  • It can be engineered for mass dissemination in the future.
  • It has the potential for high mortality and morbidity.

Examples:
  • Bacillus anthracis - Anthrax (Option B)
  • Francisella tularensis - Tularemia
  • Clostridium botulinum - Botulism
  • Yersinia pestis - Bubonic plague
  • Ebola virus - Ebola hemorrhagic fever
  • Clostridium perfringens - epsilon toxin.
  • Cryptosporidium parvum.
  • Escherichia coli (O157:H7)
  • Shigella dysenteriae.
  • Salmonella.
  • Vibrio cholera.
  • Coxiella burnetii (Option C ruled out)
  • Brucella (Option D ruled out)
  • Hantavirus
  • MDR-tuberculosis
  • Nipah Virus (Option A ruled out)
  • Yellow fever
  • Tick-borne encephalitis /hemorrhagic fever

questions.text: The test kit shown in the image below works on which principle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Immunochromatography

Explanation:

Immunochromatographic Card Tests:

  • Purpose: Rapid detection of infectious diseases including Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, COVID-19, and malaria.
  • Advantages:
    • Quick results (15-30 minutes)
    • High sensitivity and specificity
    • Useful in resource-limited settings
  • These kits work on the principle of immunochromatographic assay (ICA), also known as the lateral flow assay (LFA).
  • The technique involves:
    • Capillary action driving the sample along a membrane.
    • Antigen-antibody interaction causing a visible reaction (e.g., colored line formation).
    • Gold nanoparticles or enzyme-linked detection for visualization.

 

Disease-Specific Findings:

Disease

Type of Detection

Sensitivity (%)

Specificity (%)

Note

Hepatitis B Virus (HBV)

Antibodies (anti-HBs) or antigens (HBsAg)

> 95

> 99

Reliable for initial screening

Hepatitis C Virus (HCV)

Antibodies against HCV

90 - 98

95 - 100

Critical for quick identification

COVID-19

IgM and IgG antibodies

98.68 (IgM), 98.72 (IgG)

93.10 (IgM), 100 (IgG)

Effective for serological diagnosis

Rapid antigen tests

94.3

100

Effective for early diagnosis

Malaria

Specific antigens from malaria parasites

90 - 95

~95

Timely treatment decisions are critical

 

ELISA (Option A): Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) is a lab-based method that uses enzyme-substrate reactions to detect antigens or antibodies.

Immunofluorescence (Option C): Uses fluorescent dyes to detect antigens or antibodies under a fluorescence microscope. Used in viral diagnostics and autoimmune disease testing.

Chemiluminescence (Option D): Uses luminescent reactions to detect antigens or antibodies. Commonly used in automated analyzers for hormone assays, tumor markers, and infectious disease screening.

questions.text: Which of the following culture media is used to differentiate E. coli O157:H7 from other E. coli species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Sorbitol MacConkey (SMAC) agar

Explanation:

  • E. coli O157:H7 is a major cause of hemorrhagic colitis and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS).

  • Unlike most E. coli strains, O157:H7 does not ferment sorbitol.

  • Sorbitol MacConkey (SMAC) agar is used for differentiation:

    • E. coli O157:H7 → Colorless colonies (non-sorbitol fermenting)

    • Other E. coli → Pink colonies (sorbitol fermenting)

This combination of tests is commonly used to identify E. coli.

  • Indole Test: E. coli is typically indole positive.

  • Methyl Red Test: E. coli ferments glucose to produce stable acid, resulting in a positive MR test.

  • Voges-Proskauer Test: E. coli is usually VP negative.

  • Citrate Utilization Test: E. coli does not utilize citrate as a sole carbon source, leading to a negative result.

Results of an IMViC series done on Escherichia coli after 24-hour incubation at 37°C.

  • Tube A shows a positive indole test in tryptone broth. The positive result is indicated by the red layer at the top of the tube after adding Kovács reagent.
  • Tube B shows a positive methyl red test as indicated by the red color after the addition of methyl red reagent.
  • Tube C shows a negative Voges-Proskauer test as indicated by the lack of colour change after the addition of Barritt's A and Barritt's B reagents.
  • Tube D shows a negative citrate result as indicated by the lack of growth and color change in the tube.

Specimen Collection

  • Types of Specimens:

    • Stool Samples: For gastrointestinal infections.

    • Urine Samples: For urinary tract infections (UTIs).

    • Blood Samples: For septicemia.

    • Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF): For meningitis.

Laboratory Techniques

Microscopy

  • Gram Staining:

    • E. coli appears as Gram-negative rods.

    • Useful for preliminary identification in cases of septicemia and meningitis.

Culture Methods

  • General Media:

    • MacConkey Agar:

      • E. coli typically produces pink colonies due to lactose fermentation.

  • Selective and Differential Media:

    • Eosin Methylene Blue (EMB) Agar:

      • E. coli shows a characteristic green metallic sheen.

    • Sorbitol-MacConkey (SMAC) Agar:

      • Differentiates E. coli O157 (colorless colonies) from other E. coli strains (pink colonies).

                                                    E. coli on EMB agar

 

Sorbitol fermenting and non-fermenting colonies of Escherichia coli on sorbitol MacConkey agar.

 

Biochemical Tests

IMViC Tests

Test

Result

Indole Production

E. coli is typically indole positive.

Methyl Red (MR) Test

E. coli shows a positive result.

Voges-Proskauer (VP) Test

E. coli is typically negative.

Citrate Utilization

E. coli usually does not utilize citrate (negative result).

Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) Agar

Shows fermentation of glucose, lactose, and production of gas.

Urease Test

E. coli is urease negative.

 

Mannitol salt agar (Option A): Selective for Staphylococcus species (high salt content).

Xylose lysine deoxycholate (XLD) agar (Option B): Primarily used for Salmonella and Shigella isolation.

CLED medium (Option D): Used for urinary pathogens. Does not specifically differentiate E. coli O157:H7.

questions.text: What level of biosafety containment is required for specimen handling for molecular testing of SARS-CoV-2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) BSL 2

Explanation:

SARS-CoV-2, the causative agent of COVID-19, is classified as:

  • To perform molecular testing, a Biological Safety Level-2 (BSL-2) laboratory is required.
  • Personnel who are adequately trained and skilled should manage viral culture and isolation, which must be conducted in a BSL-3 laboratory.

Containment: Safe management of infectious agents in labs to prevent exposure.

  • Primary Containment: Protects lab workers and environment through microbiological techniques, safety equipment, and vaccines.
  • Secondary Containment: Prevents external exposure through facility design and operational practices.

Safety Equipment (Primary Barriers)

  • Biological Safety Cabinets:
    • Class I & II: Partial containment for personnel and environment.
    • Class III: Airtight for maximum protection.
  • Other Equipment: Safety centrifuge cups, gloves, gowns, respirators, face shields.
  • PPE serves as a primary barrier in high-risk activities outside BSCs.

Facility Design (Secondary Barriers)

  • Basic Labs (BSL-1 & BSL-2): Handle low-risk agents, general lab setup.
  • Containment Labs (BSL-3): Specialized ventilation, access control for handling hazardous materials.
  • Maximum Containment Labs (BSL-4): Highest security for dangerous pathogens, airlocks, decontamination systems.

Biosafety Levels

  • BSL-1: Handles non-harmful microbes (e.g., Bacillus subtilis).
  • BSL-2: Deals with moderate-risk agents (e.g., Hepatitis B, Salmonella).
  • BSL-3: Handles serious airborne pathogens (e.g., TB, St. Louis encephalitis).
  • BSL-4: Works with life-threatening, highly transmissible agents (e.g., Lassa virus).

questions.text:
When would you choose to utilize a sanitizer?


	Prior to conducting a patient examination
	Following a patient examination
	After coming into contact with the patient's environment
	On open wound
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2 & 3 only

Explanation:

  1. Prior to conducting a patient examination – Correct. Hand sanitization before patient contact reduces the risk of transmitting infections.
  2. Following a patient examination – Correct. Sanitizing hands after examining a patient prevents cross-contamination.
  3. After coming into contact with the patient's environment – Correct. Contact with surfaces in a patient's vicinity can harbor pathogens, necessitating hand hygiene.
  4. On an open wound – Incorrect. Sanitizers contain alcohol, which can cause irritation and damage to tissue when applied to open wounds.

Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

Effectiveness of Alcohol-Based Hand Sanitizers

  • Contains ethanol, isopropanol, or a mix
  • Effectiveness depends on alcohol type, concentration (60-95%), application technique, and consistency.
  • Ethanol is more effective against viruses, while propanol is better for bacteria.

WHO Definition and Composition
  • Hand sanitizers consist of alcohol (liquid, gel, or foam), excipients, humectants, and sometimes antimicrobial agents (e.g., chlorhexidine for prolonged protection).
  • Higher alcohol concentrations (above recommended levels) can be paradoxically less effective due to reduced protein denaturation.

Indications and Limitations
  • Effective against most bacteria, fungi, and enveloped viruses (e.g., SARS-CoV-2, Ebola, Zika).
  • Less effective against protozoan oocysts, non-enveloped viruses (e.g., norovirus, poliovirus), and bacterial spores (e.g., Clostridioides difficile).
  • Ineffective when hands are visibly soiled or contaminated with certain pathogens.

Contraindications and Risks
  • Can cause skin reactions like dryness, irritation, contact dermatitis, and rarely urticaria.
  • Frequent use may lead to minor alcohol absorption, though considered safe.
  • Fire hazard due to flammability

WHO-Recommended Formulations
  • Ethanol-based (80%) - Ethanol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.
  • Isopropyl alcohol-based (75%) - Isopropyl alcohol, glycerol, hydrogen peroxide, distilled water.

Proper Application Technique
  • Apply 2.4 mL sanitizer, rub thoroughly for 15-30 seconds until dry.
  • Some dispensers may not release adequate amounts; users should ensure sufficient application.

questions.text: Which of the following is the test used for antibiotic sensitivity?
questions.solution:
Antimicrobial Susceptibility Testing (AST) helps clinicians choose appropriate antibiotics by determining which drugs are effective against the specific bacteria causing the infection. AST is conducted only on pathogenic bacteria isolated from clinical specimens, not on commensal bacteria.

 

MIC is defined as the lowest concentration of an antibiotic that prevents visible growth of the microorganism in a standardized growth medium.

Minimal Inhibitory Concentration (MIC)
  • The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that inhibits the growth of the pathogen in the medium.

Minimal Bactericidal Concentration (MBC)
  • The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

Methods
  • Dilution method
  • Disc diffusion method
  • E-Test (combo of first two methods)
  • Automated methods

 

Clinical significance of MIC:

  • If MIC > breakpoint value, then there is resistance
  • If MIC < breakpoint value, then there is sensitivity

 

The lowest concentration of the antibiotic that kills the bacteria (Option C): This definition describes the minimal bactericidal concentration (MBC), not the MIC.

 

Learning Objective:

  • Minimal inhibitory concentration(MIC): The lowest concentration of the antibiotic inhibits the pathogen's growth in the medium.
  • Minimal bactericidal concentration(MBC): The lowest concentration of antibiotic that kills the bacteria in a medium.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is a process that enhances the binding strength of antibodies to their specific antigen during an immune response. Which of the following mechanisms is primarily responsible for this process?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic hypermutation

Explanation:

  • Affinity maturation occurs due to somatic hypermutation, a process in which point mutations accumulate in the variable regions of immunoglobulin genes within germinal centers of lymphoid tissues. B cells with higher-affinity receptors are selectively expanded through antigen-driven selection, leading to progressively stronger antigen binding.

The formation of antibodies, or immunoglobulins involves multiple cellular components and steps:

  1. Antigen Encounter and Recognition
    • The process begins when B cells encounter a specific antigen. This antigen must be recognized as foreign to activate the adaptive immune response.
    • B cell receptors (BCRs) on the surface of B cells bind to the antigen. This recognition is highly specific and depends on the unique variable regions of the immunoglobulin on BCRs.
  2. Activation of B Cells
    • Upon binding with the antigen, B cells become activated, which requires help from T helper (Th) cells.
    • T cells are required to release cytokines and co-stimulatory signals, which aid in the full activation of B cells, especially in the case of protein antigens.
  3. Proliferation and Clonal Expansion
    • Activated B cells undergo clonal expansion, where they proliferate to create identical cells that can produce the same specific antibody.
    • This clonal expansion amplifies the immune response, ensuring that a sufficient number of cells are available to target the pathogen.
  4. Differentiation into Plasma Cells and Memory B Cells
    • Following expansion, B cells differentiate into two main cell types:
      • Plasma Cells: These are the effector cells that actively secrete antibodies. Plasma cells are responsible for producing large quantities of antibodies, which are then released into the bloodstream.
      • Memory B Cells: These cells are long-lived and retain the memory of the specific antigen. Upon subsequent exposure to the same antigen, memory B cells can quickly initiate a secondary immune response, leading to a faster and more robust production of antibodies.
  5. Antibody Class Switching
    • Initially, B cells produce IgM antibodies. However, with the help of Th cells, B cells can undergo a process called "class switching" to produce other types of antibodies like IgG, IgA, or IgE.
    • Class switching allows the immune system to adapt the type of antibody produced to the specific requirements of the immune response, depending on the nature of the pathogen and the location of the infection.
  6. Affinity Maturation
    • Affinity maturation occurs in the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues and involves the somatic hypermutation of antibody genes.
    • This process leads to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for the antigen, allowing for a more effective immune response.
  7. Memory and Long-Term Immunity
    • Memory B cells generated during the primary response ensure long-term immunity. If the same antigen is encountered again, these cells quickly respond by differentiating into plasma cells and producing antibodies.
    • This secondary immune response is usually faster and more intense due to the Spresence of these memory cells.


Incorrect Options:

Isotype switching (Option A): Isotype switching (class switching) involves changes in the constant region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain, altering the antibody's effector function but not its antigen-binding affinity. It does not contribute to affinity maturation.

mRNA splicing (Option C): mRNA splicing is a post-transcriptional process that removes introns and joins exons in RNA molecules. While it is essential for immunoglobulin expression (e.g., determining membrane-bound vs. secreted antibody forms), it does not influence affinity maturation.

VDJ rearrangement (Option D): VDJ recombination generates the initial diversity of the B-cell receptor before antigen exposure. However, affinity maturation occurs later, after antigen stimulation, through somatic hypermutation and selection in germinal centers.

questions.text: Which type of microscope can be used to detect the motility of the probable causative organism in a truck driver presenting with painless indurated genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Dark-field microscope

Explanation:

  • The scenario described - a painless indurated genital ulcer following unprotected sexual activity - is highly suggestive of chancre, which is characteristic of syphilis caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. This bacterium is spiral-shaped and motile, and it is best visualized in its motile form using a dark-field microscope.
  • The appearance of Treponema pallidum under dark-field microscopy is a slender spiral structure with slow cork screw movement.

Specimen Collection
  • Lesion cleaned with gauze soaked in warm saline.
  • Margins gently scraped to abrade superficial epithelium.
  • Gentle pressure applied to the lesion base to collect exudate (prevent blood admixture).
  • Serum collected for serology; CSF for neurosyphilis.

Dark ground microscopy
  • Exudate collected and placed under a coverslip.
  • Examined with dark ground microscopy.
  • T. pallidum identified by slender, tightly coiled spiral structure showing slow movement.

Silver Impregnation Staining
  • Fontana’s method is used for staining smear films.
  • Levaditi’s method is preferred for tissue sections.

Incorrect Options:

Electron microscope (Option B): While an electron microscope can provide highly detailed images of the organism at a subcellular level, it is not commonly used in routine clinical settings for motility testing or diagnosing syphilis due to its complexity and the need for specialized equipment.

Light microscope (Option C) can be used to visualize organisms, but it cannot detect the motility of Treponema pallidum. The bacterium is too small and thin to be easily observed using a light microscope without the use of specific stains or techniques.

Fluorescent microscope (Option D) is typically used for detecting organisms or structures that have been labeled with a fluorescent dye. While it can be useful for other types of pathogens, syphilis diagnosis usually involves direct examination using dark-field microscopy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with fever, loose stools, and blood in the stool. Which enrichment medium is used to isolate the organism from the stool sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Selenite F broth

Explanation:

  • Selenite F medium is an enrichment medium is used primarily for stool samples to suppress gut bacteria growth while allowing diarrheagenic bacteria (Salmonella, Shigella) to grow.

Enrichment Broth:

  • Liquid media with inhibitory agents selectively promote the growth of specific organisms and inhibit others.
  • Used for isolating pathogens from clinical specimens containing normal flora (e.g., stool, sputum).

Examples:

  1. Tetrathionate broth – Used for Salmonella Typhi isolation.
  2. Gram-negative broth – Used for Shigella isolation.
  3. Selenite F broth – Used for Shigella isolation.
  4. Alkaline peptone water (APW) – Used for Vibrio cholerae isolation.
  5. Lim Broth is an enrichment broth specifically used to enhance the growth of group B streptococci. It provides the necessary nutrients and conditions for the selective multiplication of these organisms.

Incorrect Options:

Robertson cooked meat broth (Option A): This is a general-purpose enrichment medium that supports the growth of a wide variety of organisms but is not specifically selective for Salmonella or Shigella (which might also cause bloody diarrhea).

Alkaline peptone water (Option B): This medium is used for the pre-enrichment of Vibrio species (like Vibrio cholerae) and is not useful for isolating Salmonella or other enteric pathogens causing bloody diarrhea.

Brain heart infusion broth (Option D): This is a non-selective medium used for the growth of a wide range of organisms, including bacteria and fungi, but it is not specifically used for isolating enteric pathogens like Salmonella from stool samples.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2 (Lipid A)

Explanation:

Cell Wall of Gram-Negative Bacteria: 

  • Peptidoglycan layer:
    • It is thinner (1-2 layers, 2 nm) and more complex than the gram-positive cell wall.
    • Composed of a mucopeptide chain, with alternate NAM and NAG molecules.
    • The pentaglycine bridge is absent. The tetrapeptide chains are covalently linked between the D-alanine of one chain with meso-diaminopimelic acid of the adjacent chain.

  • Outer membrane (Option D ruled out):
    • It is a phospholipid layer, attached to the thin peptidoglycan layer by a membrane protein called Braun’s lipoprotein.
    • Contains outer membrane proteins (OMP), which help in transport of small molecules.
  • Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) : This layer is unique to gram-negative bacteria, consists of 3 parts (mnemonic - OPA):
    • O side chain (or O antigen or somatic antigen) (Option C ruled out): A polysaccharide chain which greatly varies in composition between bacterial strains and hence this is used for serotyping for bacteria (e.g., Salmonella typhi - widal test). It is also a major surface antigen, induces antibody formation.
    • Core polysaccharide: It is projected from lipid A region. It is composed of 10–12 sugar moieties.
    • Lipid A or the endotoxin (Option A): Responsible for endotoxic activities such as pyrogenicity, tissue necrosis, anti-tumor activity, etc.
  • Periplasmic Space: It is the space between the inner cell membrane and outer membrane. It encompasses the peptidoglycan layer.
  • Cell membrane (plasma membrane) (Option B ruled out):
    • The semipermeable membrane acts as an osmotic barrier and is composed of bilayered phospholipids.
    • Lacks sterols, such as cholesterol (except in Mycoplasma).
    • Site for metabolic processes like respiration and synthesis of lipids and cell walls.

Teichoic acids are polymers which are present only in gram-positive bacteria. These molecules help maintain the structure of the cell wall. They are of two types:

  1. Cell wall teichoic acid and
  2. Lipoteichoic acid

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is considered a strict anaerobe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prevotella

Explanation:

  • Numerous species of bacteria in the genus Prevotella are recognized as strict anaerobes.

Prevotella:

Classification

Gram-negative, Strict anaerobic, rod-shaped bacterium

Morphology

Small, pleomorphic Gram-negative rods

Habitat

Normal flora of the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract

Pathogenicity

Opportunistic pathogen, causes anaerobic infections

Clinical manifestation
  • Oral and dental infections (periodontal disease, abscesses)
  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Lung abscess
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Otitis media
  • Gynecological infections (bacterial vaginosis, pelvic inflammatory disease)

Diagnosis
  • Gram stain (Gram-negative rods)
  • Anaerobic culture
  • MALDI-TOF
  • PCR-based tests

Colony Morphology

Black-pigmented colonies on blood agar (some species)

Treatment

Metronidazole, β-lactam + β-lactamase inhibitors, Clindamycin

Resistance

Resistant to aminoglycosides

Incorrect Options:

Burkholderia cepacia (Option A) It is an obligate aerobe.

Yersinia enterocolitica (Option B) It is a facultative anaerobic bacteria, which means it can survive and grow in both the presence and absence of oxygen.

Stenotrophomonas maltophilia (Option C) is also a strictly aerobic organism.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On oral examination, a white pseudomembrane is observed. A swab from the lesion was collected and stained, as shown in the image below. What is the correct sequence for the staining procedure used?




	Albert’s stain – I
	Acid Alcohol
	Iodine
	Safranin
	Methylene blue
	Crystal violet
	Acetone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6, 3, 7, 4

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and given picture show a gram-positive bacilli arranged in a V and L shape, giving a Chinese letter or cuneiform appearance, which is suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is stained using gram stain. Metachromatic granules are visualised through albert stain.

Steps of Gram staining:

  • Fixation: involved making the smear
  • Crystal Violet Staining: Flood the slide with crystal violet for 1 minute to stain all cells purple.
  • Iodine Treatment: Add iodine solution for 1 minute, which forms a complex with the crystal violet, helping it stick to the cells.
  • Decolorization: Rinse with alcohol or acetone to remove the stain from Gram-negative cells (while Gram-positive cells retain the dye).
  • Counterstaining: Flood the slide with safranin for 30 seconds to stain Gram-negative cells pink/red.

Other Options are incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following instruments are sterilized by gamma radiation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Syringes, needles, and catheters

Explanation:

Radiation:

Ionising

Features:

  • High penetration power
  • Sporicidal action +
  • Known as Cold radiation (do not increase surface heat)
  • Examples: Gamma rays, X-rays, Cosmic rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters
  • Catgut sutures - Gamma (γ) rays

Non-ionising

Features:

  • Low penetration power
  • Only bactericidal action +
  • Examples: UV rays, infrared rays

Uses:

  • Plastics, syringes, catheters

Mechanism of action
  • DNA damage by Dimer formation

Quality control agent

  • Bacillus pumilus

Contaminated clothes and animal carcasses (Option B) These are sterilized through Incineration.

Gloves and aprons (Option C) These are usually sterilized by autoclaving processes.

Bacterial vaccines and intravenous solutions (Option D) These are usually sterilized by autoclaving at 60° C for one hour.

questions.text: Which of the following cell organelles is associated with destruction of bacteria and viruses?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Lysosomes

Explanation:

Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain digestive enzymes capable of breaking down a variety of substances, including bacteria, viruses, and cellular debris. They play a crucial role in the destruction of pathogens as part of the immune response, especially in phagocytic cells like macrophages and neutrophils.

Peroxisomes (option A): Peroxisomes are involved in the breakdown of fatty acids and detoxification of harmful substances (like hydrogen peroxide), but they do not directly participate in the destruction of bacteria and viruses.

Golgi complex (option C): The Golgi complex is responsible for modifying, sorting, and packaging proteins and lipids, not for pathogen destruction.

Ribosomes (option D): Ribosomes are involved in protein synthesis, not the destruction of pathogens.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is used for the diagnosis of Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Ziehl-Neelsen stain

Explanation:

Ziehl Neelsen stain (Acid Fast stain):

  • Principle: Acid fastness is due to the high content and variety of lipids, fatty acids, and higher alcohols in tubercle bacilli.
  • Primary Stain: Carbol Fuschin (red colour)
  • Mordant: Heat
  • Decolorizing Agent: Acid/Acid-alcohol (commonly sulphuric acid). The concentration of sulfuric acid may vary depending on the acid fastness of the structure to be demonstrated.

  • Counterstaining: The smear is counterstained with a contrasting dye such as methylene blue.
  • Result: Acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin (red) colour. Non-acid-fast bacteria take the counterstain colour (blue).

 

COLD ZN Stain (Kinyoun Stain/Gabbet Stain): Modified ZN stain where intermittent heating is not required with increased phenol concentration in carbol fuchsin, used for coccidian parasites.

Gomori Methenamine Silver (Option A)This stain is commonly used for the identification of fungi and pneumocytis jirovecii.

Prussian Blue (Option B) This stain is used to detect iron (hemosiderin) in tissue sections. For example, hemosiderin heart failure cells and ferruginous bodies in asbestosis.

Masson-Fontana Stain (Option D) This stain is utilized to detect melanin in tissues and to stain the pigmented fungi.

questions.text: The cell wall depicted below is most likely to belong to which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungus which differ from bacteria by having rigid cell walls containing chitin, mannan and polysaccharides. Cytoplasmic membrane contains sterols.

 

Property

Fungi

Bacteria
  1. Cell Structure

Eukaryote

Prokaryote
  1. Cell Wall Composition

Multilayered; chitin, mannan, and glucans

Peptidoglycan, LPS, teichoic acid
  1. Cytoplasmic Membrane

Sterols are present except in Pneumocystis carinii

Sterols are absent except in Mycoplasma
  1. Cytoplasmic Contents

Membrane-bound organelles (e.g., mitochondria, Golgi apparatus, ER)

Membrane-bound organelles absent
  1. Nucleus

True nucleus with nuclear membrane; paired chromosomes

No nucleus or nuclear membrane; single circular dsDNA chromosome
  1. Diameter

5 – 10 μm; may be > 100 μm

< 2 μm
  1. Morphology

Yeast: ovoid, round; Moulds: filamentous

Cocci, bacilli, some branching
  1. Spores

Both asexual and sexual for reproduction

Asexual (endospores) primarily for survival

 

Clinical implications:

  • Beta 1,3 glucan Antigenin serum for invasive fungal infections except Cryptococcus and Mucor/Rhizopus
  • Galactomannan test for invasive aspergillosis.

questions.text: What microscopy technique is utilized to generate a high contrast image of transparent, viable bacteria?
questions.solution:
Phase contrast microscopy is a technique that produces high-contrast images.

  • This microscope creates a contrast between living cells and water by converting slight differences in refractive index and cell density into detectable variations in light intensity, allowing for visualization of unstained cells.
  • It enables background light to be separated from specimen-diffracted light.
  • Microbial motility.
  • Determining the shape of living cells.
  • Detecting bacterial components such as endospores and inclusion bodies.
  • Reveal internal structures of living cells.

 

Darkfield microscope

  • Light is reflected.
  • Illuminates the objects.
  • Used for thin structures:
  • Flagella
  • Spirochetes

 

Interference contrast microscope

  • Reveals cell organelles.
  • Measurements of chemical constituents of cells such as:
  • Lipids
  • Proteins
  • Nucleic acids

 

Fluorescence microscope

  • Light source: UV light
  • Uses: cases of TB/ malaria/pathology of kidney biopsy
  • Immunofluorescence + fluorescent dye

questions.text: Which is true about RT-PCR method?

choices.text: DNA is first converted to RNA

questions.solution:
RT PCR involves synthesis of cDNA.

Reverse Transcription Polymerase Chain Reaction (RT-PCR):

  • Used for the detection and quantification of RNA, including viral RNA. - Widely employed in molecular biology and diagnostic applications, particularly in the detection of infectious agents like viruses.

Principle

  • Involves the reverse transcription of RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) followed by polymerase chain reaction amplification of the cDNA.

Components

  • Reverse Transcriptase (RT): Enzyme that synthesizes a complementary DNA strand from an RNA template.
  • DNA Polymerase: Enzyme responsible for synthesizing the complementary DNA strand during PCR.
  • Primers: Short DNA sequences that initiate the synthesis of the cDNA strand during reverse transcription and serve as starting points for PCR amplification.
  • Fluorescent Probes: Used for real-time detection of amplification.

questions.text: Which of the following agents can be used as a disinfectant but not as a sanitizer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Hydrogen Peroxide

 

Explanation:

Hydrogen peroxide is a powerful disinfectant. H,02 works by producing destructive hydroxyl free radicals that can attack various cell components.

  • Hydrogen peroxide is an effective disinfectant for inanimate objects and surfaces, but on animal surface it produces skin irritation, vapors may irritate the eyes and mucous membranes.
  • Hence, it is not used as a sanitizer.

 

Disinfectant:

  • A product used to kill microorganisms on inanimate objects or surfaces.
  • Examples: Alcohols, chlorine and chlorine compounds, formaldehyde, glutaraldehyde, ortho-phthalaldehyde, hydrogen peroxide, iodophors, peracetic acid, phenolics, and quaternary ammonium compounds.

 

Sanitizer:

  • A product used to kill microorganisms on living tissue
  • Examples: 60 and 95% alcohol, usually in the form of ethanol, isopropanol, or n-propanol.

questions.text: Northern blotting is used for detection of which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: (Option B)

Explanation

Northern blotting is a technique used to detect RNA sequences. It involves the separation of RNA samples by gel electrophoresis, transfer to a membrane, and hybridization with a labeled probe specific to the RNA of interest.

 

Types

Target

Features

Southern blotting

(Option A ruled out)

DNA sequences

It involves separating DNA fragments by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using labelled probes to identify specific sequences

Northern blotting

RNA sequences

(Option B)

The process is similar to DNA blotting but focuses on RNA. (Option D ruled out)

Western blotting

(Option C ruled out)

Proteins

This technique specifically detects and analyses proteins in a complex mixture. It involves separating proteins by gel electrophoresis, transferring them to a membrane, and then using specific antibodies to detect the proteins.

Eastern blotting

Post-translational modifications

It refers to specialised Western blotting techniques that detect specific post-translational modifications of proteins, such as phosphorylation or glycosylation.

Southwestern blotting

DNA-binding proteins

Combines Southern and Western blotting elements to identify proteins that bind to specific DNA sequences.

questions.text: A 32-year-old laborer working at a construction site presented with fever and hemoptysis. The sputum sample collected for examination showed the following. The smear will be stained by which of the following sequences?

choices.text: Basic fuschin - tannic acid - methylene blue

questions.solution:
correct answer (D) Carbol fuschin - acid - methylene blue.

The clinical history and the microscopy showing bright red acid-fast bacilliis is suggestive of tuberculosis, and the stain used is Ziehl Nielsen stain.

Ziehl Neelsen stain (Acid Fast stain):

  • Principle: Acid fastness is due to the high content and variety of lipids, fatty acids, and higher alcohols in tubercle bacilli.
  • Primary Stain: Carbol Fuschin (red colour)
  • Mordant: Heat
  • Decolorizing Agent: Acid/Acid-alcohol (commonly sulphuric acid). The concentration of sulfuric acid may vary depending on the acid fastness of the structure to be demonstrated.

 

  • Counterstaining: The smear is counterstained with a contrasting dye such as methylene blue.
  • Result: Acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin (red) colour. Non-acid-fast bacteria take the counterstain colour (blue).

COLD ZN Stain (Kinyoun Stain/Gabbet Stain): Modified ZN stain where intermittent heating is not required with increased phenol concentration in carbol fuchsin, used for coccidian parasites.

Gentian violet – Iodine – alcohol - safranin (Option A) This staining method is a gram stain. It is used to differentiate between gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria. The sequence of gram stains is Gentian violet – Iodine – alcohol safranin.

Malachite green - heat – water - safranin (Option B) The staining technique is Schaeffer-Fulton`s method used for staining bacterial endospores.

Basic fuschin - tannic acid - methylene blue (Option C) The staining technique is Leifson and Ryu stain to demostrate flagella.

questions.text:
​Disposable pipette tips are sterilized by which of the following methods?

a. Autoclave

b. Hot air oven

c. Microwave

d. 70% ethanol
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - a only:

  • Disposable pipettes are sterilized by autoclave

  • All plastic and rub materials are sterilized by autoclave.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C: These are incorrect options

  • Hot air oven: Sharpes, powdery and oily materials are sterilized by hot air oven.

  • Microwave: Another useful method of sterilization of small-volume waste at the point of generation, but ideally not used for animal or human body parts, metal items or toxic or radioactive material.

  • 70% ethanol: It is used in disinfection and it is a low level disinfectant.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms can thrive in an acidic pH?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lactobacilli:

  • Most pathogenic bacteria grow best between pH 7.2 and pH 7.6, but there are some exceptions.
  • Lactobacilli can grow at acidic pH below pH 4. They are commonly found in various acidic environments, such as the vagina, gastrointestinal tract, and fermented foods like yogurt and sauerkraut.
  • Vibrio cholerae can grow at alkaline pH (8.2-8.9).

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: The toughness of bacterial cell walls is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Peptidoglycan

Explanation: Toughness of bacterial cell wall is due to Peptidoglycan.

Bacterial Cell Wall:

  • Tough and rigid structure surrounding the bacterium.
  • 10-25 nm in thickness and constitutes 20-25% of the dry weight of the cell.
  • Functions of Cell Wall:
    • Provides protection to the cell against osmotic lysis.
    • Confers rigidity upon bacteria due to the presence of a peptidoglycan layer in the cell wall.
    • Protect a cell from toxic substances and is the site of action of several antibiotics.
    • Contains certain virulence factors (e.g., endotoxin), which contribute to bacterial pathogenicity.
    • Antibody raised against specific cell wall antigens (e.g., antibody to LPS) may provide immunity against some bacterial infections.

Difference between Gram-positive and Gram-negative Bacterial Cell Walls:

Gram-positive

Features

Gram-negative

Thick layer

Peptidoglycan layer

Thin layer

100 layer thick

Thickness

1–2-layer thickness

2-5 %

Lipid content

15-50%
  • Peptidoglycans+++
  • Lipoproteins
  • Teichoic acid

Composition
  • Lipopolysaccharide
  • Lipoproteins
  • Peptidoglycan+

Absent

Outer membrane

Present

Absent

Periplasmic space + Porins

Present

Present

Teichoic acid (used for

attachment)

Absent

Present

Pentapeptide cross bridge

Absent

Present

NAM-NAG

Present

Teichoic acid (Option A) is present in Gram-positive bacteria, but it mainly contributes to cell wall stability and ion transport, not toughness.

Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) (Option C) are found in Gram-negative bacteria, but they form the outer membrane, playing a role in immune evasion and permeability, not rigidity.

The outer membrane (Option D) is present in Gram-negative bacteria, providing selective permeability and protection, but the structural strength comes from peptidoglycan.

questions.text: Which of the organisms listed below are capable of producing urease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Helicobacter pylori:

Urease Positive Organisms (Mnemonic Punch Kiss)

  • Proteus mirabilis
  • Ureaplasma urealyticum
  • Nocardia
  • Cryptococcus neoformans
  • Helicobacter pylori
  • Staphylococcus Saprophyticus
  • Staphylococcus Epidermidis

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not urease positive organisms.

questions.text: Pasteurization is done at .....................
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - 63 degrees Celsius for 30 minutes:

  • Pasteurization is done to kill or inactivate harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria, viruses, and parasites while preserving the flavor and nutritional value of the product.
  • Methods of pasteurization:
    • Holder Method: 63° C for 30 minutes.
    • Flash Method: 72° C for 20 seconds. The Flash method is better as it kills Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
    • Ultra-high-temperature method: 149° C for 1-2 secs

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: DNA transfer in bacteria via phage is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Transduction:

  • DNA transfer in bacteria mediated by phages (bacteriophages) is called transduction. During transduction, a bacteriophage infects a bacterial cell and incorporates bacterial DNA into its phage particles. When these phage particles infect other bacteria, they deliver the bacterial DNA, resulting in the transfer of genetic material between bacteria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conjugation: It refers to the direct transfer of genetic material between bacteria through physical contact.

Option C - Transformation: It refers to the uptake of free DNA from the environment by bacteria.

Option D - Translation: Translation is the process by which the genetic information encoded in mRNA is used to synthesize proteins. It does not involve the transfer of DNA between bacteria.

questions.text: Sporulation occurs in this phase of bacterial growth curve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stationary Phase:

Bacterial Growth Curve:

  • It has 4 phases

 

Lag Phase

Log Phase

Stationary Phase

Dead Phase
  • No increase in the number of bacteria
  • Cell adaptation
  • Increase in size, enzymes and metabolite
  • The maximum size of bacteria is seen in end of the lag phase
  • Cell division
  • Smaller in size
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • More susceptible to antibiotics
  • Some bacteria remain viable and some are dead
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Mnemonic STAB (STAT from stationary)
    • S in sporulation
    • T in Exo Toxin production
    • A in antibiotic production
    • B in Bacteriocin production
  • Antibiotic production happens in this phase
  • Decline phase
  • Cell death or involution

Incorrect Options:
Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: An HIV patient with fever and chronic diarrhea presented to OPD. His stool was examined, and it showed the following oocysts. Identify the components used for staining the stool.

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin
Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue
Methanol, dilute carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, crystal violet
Methylene blue, iodine, acid alcohol, kinyoun carbol fuchsin

questions.solution:
Correct Option B -  Kinyoun carbol fuchsin, acid alcohol, methylene blue:

  • The presentation of diarrhea in an immunocompromised individual and the image showing an acid-fast oocyst suggestive of infection by coccidian parasites like cryptosporidium, cyclospora, and isosopora.
  • The stain used is a modification of the Ziehl Neelsen staining, in which heat is not used as a mordant, instead an increased concentration of phenol in the primary stain, i.e., carbol fuschin is used as a mordant, hence known as Cold Ziehl Neelsen staining or Gabbet's stain or Kinyoun staining 
  • Procedure of Kinyoun staining:
    • Kinyoun's carbol fuchsin: This is a modified acid-fast stain that is used to stain the Cryptosporidium oocysts. It helps visualize the oocysts under the microscope.
    • Acid alcohol: Acid alcohol (5% H2SO4 and 95% ethanol) is used as a decolorizing agent to remove excess stain from the sample.
    • Methylene blue: Methylene blue is a counterstain that is applied after the decolorization step. It helps in enhancing the contrast and visualization of the stained oocysts.

Incorrect Option:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Identify the condenser in the following image.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Below the stage:

  • In a compound microscope, the condenser is present below the stage in a compound microscope. It consists of an iris, which regulates the amount of light falling on the slide.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: Plasma sterilization makes use of ………………
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hydrogen peroxide:

  • Plasma sterilization is a low-temperature sterilization technique that utilizes the fourth state of matter.
  • It uses plasma, plasma refers to a gaseous state consisting of ions, photons, free electrons, and free radicals (such as O and OH).
  • The plasma is generated by exposing the chemical hydrogen peroxide to radiofrequency waves.
  • The plasma can penetrate small crevices and cavities, making it an effective sterilization method for complex and delicate instruments like arthroscopes and ureteroscopes.
  • Control is Bacillus stearothermophilus.
  • Sterrad is a machine used for plasma sterilization.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ethylene oxide: It is a colorless liquid that disinfects by alkylating the amino, carboxy, hydroxyl, and sulfhydryl groups in protein molecules. It is highly inflammable, highly irritant, and highly explosive and is not used in plasma sterilization.

Option B - Gamma rays: Gamma rays are ionizing radiations that causes ionization of the molecules in organisms leading to breakage of DNA.

Option D - Ultraviolet radiation: It is a nonionizing radiation that causes the destruction of nucleic acid through the induction of thymine dimers. Used for surface sterilization of air, water, and surfaces.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic method depicted in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Darkfield Microscopy:

  • Darkfield microscopy is a specialized technique used for visualizing thin structures that are difficult to see using conventional brightfield microscopy. In darkfield microscopy, the specimen appears bright against a dark background, which enhances the contrast and visibility of certain structures as seen in the image.
  • In darkfield microscopy, a special condenser is used to block the direct light from reaching the objective lens. Instead, oblique or angled illumination i.e., reflected light is employed, causing light to be scattered or refracted by the specimen. This scattered light enters the objective lens and forms the image against a dark background.
  • Darkfield microscopy is particularly useful for visualizing thin structures like flagella, treponema, and spirochetes.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Phase contrast Microscopy: Phase contrast microscopy is a different optical technique used to enhance the contrast of transparent or low-contrast specimens. It converts slight differences in refractive index and cell density into easily detectable variations in light intensity. It is useful to study microbial motility and detecting microbial internal cellular components.

Option C - Fluorescent Microscopy: Fluorescent microscopy is a method that utilizes fluorophores to label specific structures or molecules within a specimen. It requires the use of fluorescent dyes or fluorescently labeled antibodies. In fluorescent microscopy, the specimen emits fluorescence when illuminated by specific wavelengths of light, resulting in a bright, colorful image against a dark background.

Option D - Electron Microscopy: Electron microscopy uses a beam of accelerated electrons instead of light to image the specimen. It provides extremely high-resolution images, allowing for the visualization of ultrastructural details of cells and tissues.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Kirby-Bauer Method:

  • The disc diffusion method is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method, a widely used technique for antibiotic susceptibility testing. It is applied to determine the susceptibility or resistance of bacteria to different antibiotics.
  • It involves placing antibiotic discs on an agar plate that has been uniformly inoculated with the test organism, this establishes a gradient with concentration being highest near the site of the disc and decreasing with distance. After incubation, the zone of inhibition around each disc is measured, indicating the bacteria's susceptibility or resistance to the antibiotics.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Agar Dilution Method: The agar dilution method employs a dilution method where drugs are prepared and inoculated with the test bacterium into the agar.

Option C - Broth Dilution Method: Broth dilution uses a dilution method; in this, serial dilutions of antibiotics are prepared in liquid broth, against the suspension of the bacterium.

Option D - PCR-Based Assay: PCR-based assays are molecular techniques used for the detection of specific genetic material, such as DNA or RNA, of pathogens. They are not used for antibiotic susceptibility testing but rather for identifying the presence or absence of specific genetic markers or genes associated with antibiotic resistance.

questions.text: Biological indicator for determining efficacy of autoclaving is?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bacillus stearothermophilus:

  • Bacillus stearothermophilus is a spore forming heat-resistant bacterium commonly used as a biological indicator to assess the effectiveness of autoclaving (steam sterilization) processes. Its resistance to heat makes it a suitable indicator for determining if autoclaving has achieved sufficient sterilization.
  • Spore-forming organisms used as a biological indicator for sterilisation are:
    • Bacillus stearothermophilus is used as a control in autoclave and plasma sterilization.
    • Bacillus subtilis is used as a control in a hot-air oven.
    • Bacillus pumilis is used as a control in sterilization by radiation.
    • Bacillus golbigii is used as a control in gas sterilization.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Sporulation occurs in which phase of bacterial growth curve:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Stationary phase:

Bacterial Growth Curve:

  • It has 4 phases

 

Lag Phase

Log Phase

Stationary Phase

Dead Phase
  • No increase in the number of bacteria
  • Cell adaptation
  • Increase in size, enzymes and metabolite
  • The maximum size of bacteria is seen in end of the lag phase
  • Cell division
  • Smaller in size
  • Maximum metabolic activity
  • More susceptible to antibiotics
  • Some bacteria remain viable and some are dead
  • Bacterial growth ceases due to depletion of nutrients
  • Mnemonic STAB (STAT from stationary)
    • S in sporulation
    • T in Exo Toxin production
    • A in antibiotic production
    • B in Bacteriocin production
  • Antibiotic production happens in this phase
  • Decline phase
  • Cell death or involution

Incorrect Options:
Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: DNA transfer in bacteria via phage is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Transduction:

  • DNA transfer in bacteria mediated by phages (bacteriophages) is called transduction. During transduction, a bacteriophage infects a bacterial cell and incorporates bacterial DNA into its phage particles. When these phage particles infect other bacteria, they deliver the bacterial DNA, resulting in the transfer of genetic material between bacteria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conjugation: It refers to the direct transfer of genetic material between bacteria through physical contact.

Option C - Transformation: It refers to the uptake of free DNA from the environment by bacteria.

Option D - Translation: Translation is the process by which the genetic information encoded in mRNA is used to synthesize proteins. It does not involve the transfer of DNA between bacteria.

questions.text: What types of organisms are capable of surviving in temperatures as high as 100 degrees Celsius?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Geobacillus stearothermophilus:

  • Geobacillus stearothermophilus is a thermophile that can survive between the temperature range of 55°C to over 100°C.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is a psychrophile with an optimum growth below 20° C. 

Option C - Bacillus Anthrax: It is a mesophile with an optimum growth rate between 25° C - 45° C.

Option D - Staphylococcus Epidermidis: It is also a mesophile with an optimum growth rate between 25° C - 45° C.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of typhus, an antigen of Proteus is used. What is this type of antigen called?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Heterophile antigen

Explanation: Proteus antigens are classified as heterophile antigens because they cross-react with antibodies produced against Rickettsia in the diagnosis of typhus.

Weil-Felix Test:

  • Weil-Felix Test is a heterophile agglutination test that works on the principle of rickettsial antibodies showing antigenic cross-reactivity with Proteus antigens (OX 19, OX 2 and OX K strains).
  • It is a tube agglutination test where serial dilutions of a patient's serum are treated with non-motile strains of P. vulgaris OX 19 and OX 2 and P. mirabilis OX K.

Disease

Agglutination Test Result

Epidemic and endemic typhus

Mainly agglutinates with OX19; sometimes with OX2

Tick-borne Spotted Fever

Antibodies to both OX19 and OX2 elevated.

Scrub Typhus

Raised antibodies to OXK

Rickettsial Pox, Q Fever, Ehrlichiosis, Bartonellosis

Negative test
  • False-positive titer - Due to underlying Proteus infection. Hence, fourfold rise of antibody titer in paired sera is better than a single high titer.
  • False-negative titer - Due to excess antibodies in the patient's sera (prozone phenomenon). This can be obviated by testing with serial dilutions of the patient's serum.

Sequestered antigens (Option A) are normally hidden from the immune system due to anatomical barriers (e.g., myelin basic protein, lens proteins of the eye, sperm-associated antigens). When exposed after trauma, infection, or inflammation, they may trigger autoimmune reactions (e.g., sympathetic ophthalmia, multiple sclerosis).

Superantigens (Option B) are highly potent immune activators that bypass normal antigen presentation by directly binding to MHC class II molecules and T-cell receptors, leading to massive cytokine release and systemic immune activation. Examples include:

  • Staphylococcal enterotoxins (food poisoning)
  • Toxic shock syndrome toxin (TSST-1)
  • Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxins (scarlet fever, toxic shock syndrome)
     

Isoantigens (or alloantigens) (Option C) are antigens that vary among individuals of the same species, such as blood group antigens (ABO, Rh) and HLA antigens. These play a role in blood transfusion compatibility and organ transplantation but are not relevant in the diagnosis of typhus.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to sterilize a glass petri dish?

choices.text: Autoclaving at 121 degrees Celsius for 30-60 minutes
Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes
Autoclaving at 134 degrees Celsius for 3 minutes
Hot air oven at 121 degrees Celsius for 30-60 minutes

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes:

  • The method used to sterilize a glass petri dish is a hot air oven at 160 degrees Celsius for 120 minutes.
  • Hot air oven uses dry heat for the sterilization of materials that may be damaged by moist heat or that are impenetrable to moist heat. 
  • This method involves heating the petri dish at a high temperature in a dry oven, which leads to the oxidation of the cell constituents.
  • The most common cycles used are:
    • 170°C for 60 minutes,
    • 160°C for 120 minutes,
    • 180°C for 30 minutes.
  • Materials sterilized are:
    • Glassware
    • Cotton swabs
    • Gel, oil, wax, Dusting powder.
    • Greasy paraffin wax
    • Metallic instruments.

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, C and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: If a sample is cultured in LJ media, what is the likely staining characteristic of the cultured organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Acid Fast:

  • LJ (Lowenstein-Jensen) media is used for the cultivation of Mycobacterium species, which are acid-fast bacteria.  
  • In acid-fast staining, the bacteria are stained with a carbol fuchsin dye and then treated with acid and alcohol. 
  • Acid-fast bacteria retain the red color of the dye even after acid and alcohol treatment, while non-acid-fast bacteria are decolorized and appear blue when counterstained with methylene blue.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is specifically found in gram-negative bacteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Lipopolysaccharide:

  • Gram-negative bacteria have a distinctive cell wall structure that includes an outer membrane, a thin peptidoglycan layer, and an inner plasma membrane.
  • Lipopolysaccharides serves as an endotoxin and is responsible for the toxic effects associated with gram-negative bacterial infections.

Difference between gram positive and negative bacteria cell wall are:

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option C for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms cannot be grown on an artificial culture media?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mycobacterium leprae:

  • Mycobacterium leprae is an obligate intracellular pathogen causing leprosy, aka Hansen’s disease, cannot be grown on artificial culture media.
  • It can be grown in cell lines like the footpads of mice or nine-banded armadillo.
  • Other bacteria which are not cultivated on artificial media are:
    • Rickettsia.
    • Chlamydia.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Staphylococcus aureus: It is a Gram-positive bacterium that can grow on various artificial culture media such as blood agar, chocolate agar, and MacConkey agar.

Option C - Mycobacterium tuberculosis: It is a slow-growing bacteria that requires special culture media such as Lowenstein-Jensen medium or Middlebrook 7H10 agar for growth.

Option D - Streptococcus pneumoniae: It is a Gram-positive bacterium that can grow on various culture media such as blood agar, chocolate agar, and MacConkey agar.
